Although arising, etc. exist separately from the characterized, arising simultaneously with the characterized dharmas, there is no fault of a single dharma being produced, abiding, changing, and ceasing at one time, because the substance is not the same and the functions are distinct.

If one grasps that apart from the characterized there are no separate arising, etc., and that each moment has four characteristics, such faults cannot be cured, because the distinctions in function of a single dharma at one time are not logically possible.

If one allows that apart from the characterized there are separate arising, etc., there is no such fault, because the substance of the characteristics is not the same, the assisting conditions are distinct, and the time periods and functions are logically different.

However, conditioned dharmas have different states, which are roughly of three kinds: because of the difference in the function of attracting effects, which has not yet been obtained, is being obtained, and has already ceased.
These conditioned dharmas are also of two kinds: those with activity and those that merely have substance.
The former is present, and the latter is past and future. Each of these has two kinds, namely, superior and inferior power.
If conditioned dharmas can act as causes to attract their own effects, this is called function.

If they can act as conditions to assist other kinds, this is called power.ğŸ”½If there is a separate dharma that, when it has not yet obtained the function of attracting effects, is assisted by external conditions that have not yet been obtained, are being obtained, or have already ceased, and gives rise to the power of internal conditions that assist in accomplishing its own affairs, this is called the characteristic of birth.

Or, there may be a dharma that, when it is in the process of obtaining the function of attracting effects, is assisted by external conditions that have not yet been obtained, are being obtained, or have already ceased, and gives rise to the power of internal conditions that assist in accomplishing its own affairs.

The other three characteristics, in the state of being born, are the internal conditions that give rise to dharmas that are born. When they reach the state of being born, these dharmas that are born are called arisen. In the state of perishing, abiding is the internal condition that stabilizes the dharma that abides, causing it to attract its own effect. When it reaches the state of having perished, this dharma that abides is called able to attract its own effect, which is precisely the state of perishing.
Perishing is the internal condition that destroys the dharma that is perishing. When it reaches the state of having perished, this dharma that is perishing is called perished.
The characteristic of difference is also like this, as should be known according to the circumstances.
Other masters say:
Because causes must rely on place, world, time, state, and companions in order to give effects.
After arising, the distinctions in function arise. This means that there are causes that rely on place to give effects. For example, rain must rely on the place of clouds in order to arise.
One must rely on the vajra seat of JambudvÄ«pa in order to realize supreme perfect enlightenment.
Or there are causes that depend on the world and its results, such as the cause of retribution and the cause of the stage of liberation, which can only give results when they are in the past.
Or there are causes that depend on time and give results, such as the karma of a wheel-turning king, which can only obtain the position of a wheel-turning king when the eon is increasing.
Or there are causes that depend on state and give results, such as seeds, which can only produce sprouts when they reach a changed state.

Although the substance of the first pure mind and light, etc. existed previously, they can only function in the future when they are in the state of arising. Or there are causes that depend on companions and give results.
Such as the four great elements, mind, mental factors, etc., which can only function when they are accompanied by companions.

Due to these distinctions, the correct principle of dependent origination, the different stages of the arising of the four characteristics, are as follows: When just arising, the characteristic of birth performs its function. When it reaches the stage of having arisen, abiding, changing, and ceasing, the three perform their respective functions at the same time.
Since the four characteristics function at different times, there is no error in saying that a single dharma is produced, endures, ages, and is destroyed at one time.

Moreover, when it is about to be destroyed, the dharma that is characterized by these characteristics temporarily endures because the characteristic of endurance is its dominant condition. It is able to attract its own effect. At that very moment, because the characteristic of aging is its dominant condition, it causes it to decay. At that very moment, because the characteristic of destruction is its dominant condition, it causes it to be destroyed. Therefore, there is no error in saying that the three characteristics exist at one time.

When the dharma that is characterized by these characteristics is called enduring, it is called decaying and changing, and it is called being destroyed. Because of the power of the characteristics, the characterized dharma is said to have three meanings at one time, depending on the point of view.
What is the characteristic of aging?

It is the decay of the dharma that is characterized by endurance. It is able to attract its own effect. Its power damages the power of the characteristic of endurance, causing the subsequent effect to be produced in a way that is inferior to the prior cause. This is the power of the characteristic of aging.
The subsequent effect gradually becomes inferior because the cause has changed.
This result is also due to the arising together of different characteristics as conditions, which can cause the subsequent result to be even worse than the previous.
In this way, the continuity of all conditioned phenomena in each moment causes the subsequent to be different, so the meaning of difference in each preceding moment is established.
Since this meaning is established, it should be used as an inference.
That is to say, because the last is seen to have differences, the preceding moments must have differences.
If that is so, when the continuity gradually increases, the differences should not exist, because the result is not seen.
There is no such fault, because at that time the characteristic of abiding is assisted by external conditions, whose power is greatly increased, and subdues the differences.
If arising exists in the future, and the arising causes the dharmas to be produced, why do not all future dharmas arise at once?
Because the causes that can produce them are always combined.
This has already been explained.
What was explained earlier?

That is, there is a separate dharma that, when the function of attracting a result has not yet been obtained, is grasped by encountering what has not yet been obtained, is correctly obtained, and has ceased. When the function of attracting a result is obtained, external conditions assist in grasping. With regard to accomplishing its own affairs, it generates the power of internal conditions assisting in grasping. This is called the characteristic of birth.
Moreover, there is a theory that says: Because causes must depend on place, world, time, and companions in order to give results.
Based on this meaning, the following statement is made.
The verse says:
Birth can give rise to what is born, but not apart from the combination of causes and conditions.
The treatise says:

Apart from the combination of the remaining causes and conditions, the power of the characteristic of birth alone cannot give rise to what is born, and therefore not all future [dharmas] arise suddenly.

Although the characteristic of birth acts as a proximate cause that arises together, it can give rise to the conditioned dharmas that are born, but it must necessarily depend on the causes of its own kind that precede it, and on the combination of assistance from other external conditions.
Just as the various causes and conditions such as seeds and earth assist in the arising of sprouts and cause the arising of sprouts, etc.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
If this is so, we only see that causes and conditions have the power to produce, and there is no separate characteristic of production.
When causes and conditions come together, dharmas are produced. Without them, they are not produced. What need is there for a characteristic of production?
Therefore, there should only be production by the power of causes and conditions.
This criticism is unreasonable, because the same criticism applies to the view that only the coming together of causes and conditions produces dharmas.
That is to say, if one only allows that future dharmas are produced by the coming together of causes and conditions, this criticism is the same.
If there is no difference between the causes and conditions of future dharmas, why do they not all arise suddenly?
Moreover, since the remaining ones are complete in the causes and conditions, the effect should also be produced.
For example, the eye faculty is drawn by past karma. Even if it is separated from the great elements, it should still be produced.
Or it should be said that the eye faculty is produced only by the power of the great elements, not by past karma.
Or the great elements drawn by past karma that can produce the eye faculty are never out of step. When one is produced, the others should also arise.

Or else, the primary elements have no power with regard to the eye, because the eye is not seen apart from the primary elements of the former eye, and the later eye is produced only on the basis of the former eye. If you admit that the primary elements have the power to produce, then this power is useless.
Again, just as seeds, water, soil, etc., are not all present at the same time, and the sprout does not necessarily arise.
Therefore we know that the power of seeds, etc., is fully realized in the production of the eye, etc.
The power of the primary elements of earth, etc., to produce is not directly perceived.
Since the power of the primary elements is not directly perceived, they should not be causes producing the eye, etc.
Again, who is the obstacle to the transformation of the continuity of the seeds of karma that you maintain, so that it cannot suddenly produce all the results of karma?
If the seeds of karma are able to produce only when assisted by conditions, then the conditions alone should be able to produce. Why bother with the seeds of karma?
Because the results of karma are produced only when assisted by many conditions. If the conditions are absent, the results are not produced.

Since the seeds of karma are not without existence when they rely on the assistance of conditions, even though they rely on many conditions, how can you deny the existence of the characteristics of production?
Moreover, in the arising of the various consciousnesses such as the eye consciousness, the scriptures say:
Even though there is an eye and form, if the attention is absent, the eye consciousness does not arise.
However, it is said that the arising of consciousness has as its condition the eye and form. Therefore, you should not object, saying:
How can the power of the cause of arising give rise to the characteristic of birth?
Moreover, when the first moment of pure dharmas arises, birth can be the cause that gives rise to the acquisition of pure dharmas. The self-nature of acquisition has already been fully established.
One should explain that apart from birth, what other dharma can be the cause that arises simultaneously with acquisition?
If there is absolutely no cause, acquisition should not arise. Then the first pure dharma should not be said to be established.
When the characteristic of birth arises, does it also have a cause that arises simultaneously with it? One should not say that it does, namely, the one effect dharma apart from the essence of birth.
How does the difference between birth and cessation assist the cause of birth?
The ancient masters all gave this explanation:
Dharmas that have the same effect are mutually causes of each other, just as the various great elements mutually assist each other.
There is another explanation:
Because all conditioned dharmas are the nature of arising, etc., when each of the four characteristics of arising, etc. functions, it uses this as its door, and the others all assist it.
Therefore, the arising of arising and the arising of the dharma to be produced are well established in principle without relying on causes and conditions.
The extensive discernment of the characteristics of conditioned dharmas is as explained in the NyÄyÄnusÄra and the PaÃ±caskandha.
The characteristics of conditioned dharmas have been briefly distinguished.
What is the meaning of the categories such as the aggregate of names?
Verse:
The so-called aggregate of names, etc. are the general terms for concepts, phrases, and letters.
Treatise:
Etc. includes the aggregate of phrases and the aggregate of syllables.
The aggregate of names, phrases, and syllables are explained in the Abhidharma.
All concepts are generally called the aggregate of names, all phrases are generally called the aggregate of phrases, and all letters are generally called the aggregate of syllables.
General terms means the meaning of combination, because in the meaning of combination, the realm of onomatopoeia is explained.

Thought refers to the thoughts of eyes, ears, vases, clothes, etc., that is, the thoughts generated by the established names that discriminate and grasp at various dharmas. Such a thought body is precisely the name body, referring to eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, mind, etc.
Chapter refers to the explanation of a chapter.

Worldly discourse is explained as the inexhaustible explanation that brings together the chapters, which can ultimately explain the meaning one wishes to speak of, which is precisely the merit that attracts pleasant ripening, etc.
Such a chapter body is precisely the sentence body, as it is said:
Merit attracts pleasant ripening, all desires are as one wishes,
and one quickly realizes the supreme, eternal quiescence of nirvana.
Such are the sentences, etc.
Letter refers to the letters a, Ä, i, Ä«, etc. Such a letter body is precisely the text body, referring to the letters ka, kha, ga, etc.
Some other masters say that in the original treatise it is said:
What is a multitude of name bodies?
It refers to names, names, things, etc.
The logicians do not wish to discuss the real characteristics of names, etc., but rather ask about them in terms of their provisional combination.
Therefore, their question about the many name-aggregates, etc., definitely should ask about the real characteristics of names, etc.
In the investigation of the real characteristics of names, etc., what use is there to examine the provisional combination of names, etc.?

Moreover, the three characteristics of names, etc., are as follows: That which is manifested by sound, which manifests meaning, which is established by convention as the definitive measure of the expressible, which reveals the self-nature of the known object that arises from the intention to be understood, which is like a reflection or echo, this characteristic is a name.
If one is able to analyze the broad and concise categories within the known object, this characteristic is a phrase.
In the state where the sound of the speaker has ceased, still causing one to fix one's attention and not be confused, transmitting it to others, this characteristic is a syllable.
Here, a name is that which conforms to and goes to, like the sound of speech to which one goes.
In this way, names follow along with intrinsic natures and are used to call out to them.
Phrases are able to explain the meaning that is spoken of, referring to being able to analyze the gates of differentiated meanings.
Words are able to make something manifest, because by relying on this and by this, that is made manifest.

This is precisely letters, referring to causing attention to be focused without forgetting, or moreover, because of being upheld by this, one is without doubt, or is able to uphold that and transmit it to others.

There is a saying that just as for one in meditative concentration, the characteristics of the expedient realm serve as a ladder to the realm that is realized in meditative concentration, so it is with words, names, phrases, and meanings.

In reality, the aggregates of names, phrases, and words are all non-associated compositional factors, but in the sÅ«tras and treatises, those dharmas that are not form are called names, because the characteristics of form are evident and the name is established based on the intrinsic nature, while the characteristics of what is not form are hidden and the name is established based on the meaning that is conveyed.
Is meaning something that can be spoken or not?
In reality, it should be said that meaning cannot be spoken.
However, they are established together, because one understands the meaning through hearing words, names are produced based on language, and names manifest the meaning.
Dharmas of the three times each have three names, called past, future, and present, because they are spoken of in three periods of time.
Moreover, there are no dharmas without names. If they existed, they would become objects of cognition that are not known.
Therefore the BhagavÄn spoke such words:
Names can illuminate everything, there is nothing that surpasses names.
Therefore in one dharma, names all follow and act freely.
Other masters say:
The meaning is less, but the names are more, because there are many names for one meaning.
Other masters further say:
The names are less, but the meaning is more, because names are only categorized as one element and a small part, but the meaning includes all eighteen elements.

There are also those who say that each has less or more, meaning that if categorized in terms of elements, the meaning is more and the names are less. If based on the establishment of teachings, the meaning is less and the names are more, because the Buddha World-Honored One has established countless names for each dharma according to the meaning.
As with craving, it is also called love, fire, snake, creeper, thirst, net, poison, spring, river, long, wide, needle and thread, and so on. The author of the treatise says this:

Isn't it that these three have language as their nature, so they use sound as their substance, and are categorized as the nature of form? How can they be said to be mental factors not associated with mind?
This criticism is unreasonable.
Why is it so?
Because the evidence of principle and teaching clearly proves that they exist separately.
The teaching refers to the power of the scriptures and the power of the words.
If the words are the same as the language, what is the point of separate explanation?
Moreover, it is said that one should uphold the correct Dharma and the words and phrases.
Moreover, it is said to rely on the meaning and not on the words.
Moreover, it is said that the cause of the gÄthÄs is called chanda, and the chanda of the words means that the measure of the composition uses language as its substance.
Moreover, a sÅ«tra says:
Knowing the Dharma and knowing the meaning. The Dharma refers to names, etc., and the meaning refers to what is expressed.
Also, a scripture says:
The words and meanings are skillfully wondrous.
Also, it says:
One should recite the true Dharma with well-spoken words and phrases. The meaning of the true Dharma recited with poorly spoken words and phrases is difficult to understand.
Also, it says:
The TathÄgata has attained the rare name, phrase, and syllable aggregates.
Also, it says:
The phrases that accord with various understandings are extremely rare.
Based on these teachings, it is known that there are separate name, phrase, and syllable aggregates that express various meanings. Their substance is like sound, real and not provisional.

Reason refers to the present observation that sometimes one obtains sound but does not obtain letters, and sometimes one obtains letters but does not obtain sound. Therefore, it is known that their substances are separate.
As for sometimes obtaining sound but not obtaining letters, it means that although one hears the sound, one does not understand the meaning.
It is presently seen that some people roughly hear the words of others and then ask again:
What did you say?
This person who hears the spoken sound but does not understand the meaning is entirely due to not yet understanding the words that are expressed.
How can one then insist that words are not different from sound?
Sometimes one obtains the letters but not the sounds, which means that one understands the meaning without hearing the sounds.
We can see that there are people who do not hear the words of others but know what is being said by seeing the movement of their lips, etc.
This is because those who do not hear the sounds but understand the meaning are all due to having already mastered the texts that are being uttered.
By this reasoning, we know that texts must be different from sounds.
Moreover, we see in the world that people chant spells while keeping the sounds low, so we know that the letters of the spells are different from the sounds of the spells.
Moreover, we see in the world that there are two debaters, with similar speech sounds, one losing and one winning. The causes of this victory and defeat must be different from the sounds.
Moreover, the two unobstructed knowledges of dharmas and language have different objects, so we know that letters are separate from sounds.
Therefore, sounds are merely the characteristics of speech sounds, without distinction. The twists and turns within them must rely on ka, ca, á¹­a, ta, pa, etc.

One must give rise to the various letters through the sounds of speech. The various letters come together in sequence to produce names. Once these names are produced, they are then able to express meanings.
Because of this, they say in turn:
Speech can issue forth names, and names can manifest meaning.
Therefore, the principle that names and sounds are different is completely established.
One should know that in this case, sound is that which can speak, and names, etc. are that which is spoken. Meaning is neither of the two. In this way, it is established without error.
Here, the master of the sutra says this:
It is not only sounds that are called speech.ğŸ”½Only those sounds that can make the meaning known are called speech.
This means that regarding various meanings, the speaker has already established the definite measure of what can be used to explain.
If the meaning of this sentence can be manifested by names, and sound can explain, then why are names, etc. necessary?
What is called the definite measure of what can be used to explain?
Isn't it that regarding meaning, one establishes the name of thought together. This is called the definite measure of what can be used to explain.
This means that regarding various meanings, the speaker has already established these characters together, which can definitely explain such and such meanings in turn.
Because of the common establishment of such letters, names are produced from such letters. These names are the definite means of expression.

When speakers are about to speak, they must first contemplate such definite means. Because of this, whether speaking by oneself or speaking by others, one is able to understand the meaning that is being expressed.

Therefore, sound alone is not able to express meaning. It is necessary for speech to produce letters, and letters further produce names. Names are then able to express the meaning that is being spoken of.
Just as speech produces letters and letters further produce names, one should contemplate the principle of producing phrases in the same way.
Here the author of the treatise says this again:
Moreover, it is not yet understood how names are produced by speech.
Is it because speech manifests them or because speech produces them?
If it is because speech produces them, since speech has the nature of sound, all sounds should be able to produce names.

If it is said that the sound that produces names has distinctions, this is sufficient to express meaning. What need is there to wait for separate names?ğŸ”½Here the author of the treatise says this again:
If names are manifested by speech, then all sounds should be able to manifest names, because speech is by nature sound.
If it is claimed that there is a difference in the sounds that manifest names, then these sounds are sufficient to manifest meaning. What need is there to assume the existence of names?
The same difficulty is encountered if you claim that sound is able to express.
If the substance of sound is able to manifest meaning, then all sounds should be able to manifest meaning.
If it is claimed that there is a difference in the sounds that manifest meaning, then this difference should be the name.
Therefore the criticism that we have made is not without merit.
However, the speaker first stores in the mind the names that he wishes to use, and then he reflects,

I will now utter such and such words in order to proclaim such and such meanings to others.ğŸ”½As a result, he later utters speech in accordance with his thoughts, and from speech there is the emission of syllables, and syllables in turn emit names, and names finally manifest meaning.
It is on the basis of this process that it is said that speech emits names and that names are able to manifest meaning.
This establishment of the relationship between names and meaning is inevitable.
If names do not first exist in the mind as aggregates, even if one speaks completely, there will be no definite indication of meaning, and others will not understand the meaning.
Moreover, the author of the treatise says:
Or one should only hold that there is a separate textual form, which is collectively called the body of names, etc. If one further holds that there is something else, it would be useless.
This is also unreasonable, because there are no texts that occur simultaneously.
Since they do not occur simultaneously, how can they be collectively assembled?
Or, just as trees, etc. are composed of the four great elements, without relying on them, shadows are separately produced. Shadows are produced by imagination, but their substance is not imaginary.
In the same way, texts should also be collectively assembled to separately produce names and phrases.
Although those names and phrases are produced by imagination, their substance is not imaginary.
If that is so, then all imaginary dharmas could be established as real existences.
There is no such fault, because there are also names in a single syllable.
There are no imaginary dharmas that are formed by combining a single real entity, so the meaning of imagination and name is not similar.
Since a name can be established for a single syllable, how can it be known that the name exists apart from the syllable?

In this way, a single syllable is like a meaningless syllable and has nothing to be expressed. Relying on this as a condition, a separate name arises that is then able to indicate the meaning, but it is extremely close and its distinct characteristics are difficult to know.
It is like the two colors of light on a wall, which are difficult to distinguish.
If it is accepted that sound itself, due to prior agreement, can, through the proclamation of distinctions, indicate meaning and is called name, etc.,
what fault is there in this?
This is also not so, because the agreement that can indicate is logically not established as a distinction of sound.
If the agreement that is established together is the distinction of sound, then it should be like the distinction of color, which can be known even without an established agreement.
The distinction of the two colors blue and yellow is not necessarily known only after an established agreement.

Although in the two colors no common agreement to distinguish them has been established previously, since blue and yellow are not different from color, when the eye consciousness has perceived them, the mental consciousness can immediately distinguish their differences.

Moreover, it is not reasonable to make an agreement on an agreement, therefore it should not be said that the agreement that is the means of expression is not different from sound, but that no common agreement has been established previously.
Although one who has obtained sound may still wait for others to establish an agreement, he is still unable to understand the difference between this and other sounds.

Moreover, if the established agreement is a difference in sound, then although no common agreement to distinguish it has been established previously, one should still be able to understand the difference between meaningful and meaningless sounds, namely that in one sound there is this difference, but in other sounds this difference does not exist.

When one hears the two sounds, although one does not understand the meaning, one should be able to understand the distinction between sounds with and without an agreement, just as one distinguishes the two colors.
Therefore, we know that apart from sound there are distinct name, phrase, and syllable aggregates that arise based on sound and are able to manifest meaning.
Moreover, the author of the treatise says:
The momentary sounds cannot be accumulated, nor does a single dharma gradually arise in parts.
How can the arising of names be caused by speech?
He also explains himself:
How is it that it depends on the past moments of indication, and the final moment of indication is able to give rise to non-indication?
He further questions himself:
If so, then the sound in the final stage gives rise to the name, but hearing only the final sound should be able to understand the meaning.
If one holds this view, that speech gives rise to writing, and writing further gives rise to names, and names then manifest meaning,
the error in this case should be the same as what was said before, because the moments of writing cannot be accumulated.
The words manifest the name, and the error should be like the arising of the name.
Moreover, if the text is manifested or produced by the words, then the words with respect to the name are not reasonable in either case.
This objection contradicts their own accepted doctrine.

They say that the past and future both lack intrinsic nature. The preceding and subsequent moments of sound cannot be produced all at once. How then can they form a text, form a name, or form a sentence?
If the preceding moments transmit and assist each other, and the final moment forms the text, name, and sentence, then hearing only the final moment should make the meaning understood.
Moreover, there is no mutual assistance, because the past and future do not exist.
Since they are always one moment, how can they mutually assist each other?

Since there is no mutual assistance, the preceding and subsequent moments are similar. The later moment should not be able to express meaning, like the initial moment. Hearing the later moment should not understand the meaning, like hearing the initial moment.
Therefore, their assertion that the preceding and subsequent moments mutually assist each other, and that sound is able to express meaning, is not established.
Our school holds that the three times all exist and are not nonexistent. Therefore, the later [moments] depend on the earlier to produce names, etc.

Although the name, etc., are produced in the final moment, one who only hears them cannot understand the meaning, because one does not hear completely, as the agreement on the name, etc., that was established previously is able to produce sound.
However, there are those who understand by hearing one sound, because of familiarity.
Based on this, the other is inferred. Therefore the author of the treatise says:
Refuting that is not this.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say that the three of name, phrase, and syllable each have three kinds.
The three kinds of name are: name, name aggregate, and many name aggregates. Phrases and syllables are also like this.
Name has many states, arising from one syllable, two syllables, or many syllables.
For those arising from one syllable, when one syllable is spoken, there is only name. When two syllables are spoken, it is called a name aggregate.
Some say:
When three syllables are spoken, it is called a many name aggregate.
Some say:
When four syllables are spoken, it is called a many name aggregate.
As for the two-syllable case, when two syllables are spoken, there is only name. When four syllables are spoken, it is called a name collection.
Some say:
When six syllables are spoken, it is called a collection of many names.
Some say:
When eight syllables are spoken, it is called a collection of many names.
As for the many-syllable case, the three-syllable case, when three syllables are spoken, there is only name. When six syllables are spoken, it is called a name collection.
Some say:
When nine syllables are spoken, it is called a collection of many names.
Some say:
When twelve syllables are spoken, it is called a collection of many names.
This is the gate, and the other many-syllable cases follow.
The many-name case and the many-name collection case should be explained in the same way.
Phrases also have many states, such as middle phrases, first phrases, last phrases, short phrases, and long phrases.
If a phrase is produced by eight syllables, it is called a middle phrase, because it is neither long nor short, so it is called middle.
Thirty-two syllables produce four sentences. In this way, four sentences form a Å›loka. The compositions of sÅ«tras and Å›Ästras often rely on this number.
If more than six syllables are produced, it is called the initial sentence. If less than twenty-six syllables are produced, it is called the subsequent sentence.
If less than six syllables are produced, it is called a short sentence. If more than twenty-six syllables are produced, it is called a long sentence.
For now, relying on the middle-length sentence, when eight syllables are spoken, it is only a sentence. When sixteen syllables are spoken, it is called a sentence body.
Some say:
When twenty-four syllables are spoken, it is called many sentence bodies.
Some say:
When thirty-two syllables are spoken, it is called many sentence bodies.
Because a written character is a syllable, there is only one category.
When one syllable is spoken, it is only a written character. When two syllables are spoken, it is called a written character body.
Some say:
When three syllables are spoken, it is called many written character bodies.
Some say:
When four letters are spoken, there are many name-bodies.

For this reason, it should be said that when one letter is spoken, there is a name but no name-body or many name-bodies, no sentences, no sentence-bodies, or many sentence-bodies, and there is writing but no writing-body or many writing-bodies.
When two letters are spoken, there is a name and a name-body but no many name-bodies, and no three such as sentences, and there is writing and a writing-body but no many writing-bodies.
When four letters are spoken, there are three such as names, and no three such as sentences, and there are three such as writing.
When eight letters are spoken, there are three such as names, and there is a sentence but no sentence-body or many sentence-bodies, and there are three such as writing.
When sixteen letters are spoken, there are three such as names, and there is a sentence and a sentence-body but no many sentence-bodies, and there are three such as writing.
When thirty-two letters are spoken, the three of name, sentence, and writing each have three kinds.
Based on this, the rest can be explained according to reason.
One should further contemplate: To which realm are such names, etc. bound?
Are they sentient or non-sentient?
Are they born of retribution, or nourished, or of the nature of outflow?
Are they wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate?
